title: House Antitrust Report Targets Big Tech Monopoly Power And Urges Breakup
text: Coercive antitrust intervention is the original sin of the administrative state, and its very presence is highly destructive of wealth. Never learning from its failures and aiming decade after decade at America's greatest innovators on the economic frontier, we deserve better from policymakers.

title: How Big Tech companies gain and maintain dominance
text: Democrats from a U.S. House of Representatives subcommittee issued a report on Tuesday detailing tactics it said four of the biggest technology companies used to gain dominant positioning in online search, advertising, social networking shopping and other businesses.

title: Facebook is a social network monopoly that buys, copies or kills competitors, antitrust committee finds
text: The House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee determined Facebook wields monopoly powers in social network and has maintained its position by acquiring, copying or killing its competitors, according to a report released by the subcommittee on Tuesday.

title: Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Google Are Monopolists, House Antitrust Subcommittee Finds, Seeks Changes
text: A House Subcommittee has concluded after a 16-month probe that four tech giants – Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google — are monopolists and wants Congress to change antitrust laws to force the companies to split off businesses or make it harder for them to buy smaller rivals. Basically, the group needs to be reined in,

title: House Committee Seeks Breakup of Giant Internet Platforms
text: Oct.06 --  A House panel proposed a series of far-reaching antitrust reforms to curb the power of U.S. technology giants including Amazon.com Inc. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google. Bloomberg's Brad Stone reports on "Bloomberg Technology."

title: Trading the tech sector in light of antitrust probe: Mahaney
text: RBC Capital's Mark Mahaney on the tech trade. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Dan Nathan and Jeff Mills.

title: Congress' Big Tech investigation finds companies wield 'monopoly power'
text: A 16-month congressional investigation into Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook has found that the tech giants hold "monopoly power" in key business segments and have abused their dominance in the marketplace, in a full-throated condemnation of the giants.

title: House panel report likens Big Tech to ‘oil barons and railroad tycoons’
text: "Companies that were once scrappy, underdog startups that challenged the status quo have become the kinds of monopolies we last saw in the era of oil barons and railroad tycoons," the report reads.

title: Lawmakers Issue Antitrust Report on Apple, Alphabet, Amazon and Facebook
text: A House subcommittee on antitrust released a 450-page report on anti-competitive practices by Amazon, Alphabet, Facebook and Apple.

title: Long-Awaited House Report Recommends Breaking Up Big Tech
text: Democrats have criticized large tech companies for anti-competitive behavior.

title: Facebook's Path To $1.2Tn: An Asymmetric Risk-Reward Opportunity
text: Facebook's superior social media product offerings used by half the world's population — Facebook, Whatsapp, Instagram and Messenger — are unparalleled and provide a competitive moat.

title: This will be a long process, these companies may not be impacted: MS's Mike Wilson on Big Tech regs
text: Mike Wilson, Morgan Stanley’s chief U.S. equity strategist and chief investment officer, joins 'Closing Bell' to provide his insight after the House antitrust subcommittee released recommendations for Big Tech companies in regards to antitrust.

title: House antitrust subcommittee releases recommendations for Big Tech
text: CNBC's Kayla Tausche reports the House antitrust subcommittee released recommendations for companies like Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon, which enjoy their monopoly of market share in the tech space. Some recommendations include structural separation of businesses and prohibiting them from being in adjacent-line of businesses.

title: House Lawmakers Condemn Big Tech’s ‘Monopoly Power’
text: In a report led by Democrats, lawmakers said Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook needed to be checked and recommended reforming antitrust laws.

title: Congress says Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple abused monopoly power
text: The report says the tech giants "run the marketplace while also competing in it."

title: U.S. congressional panel details Big Tech's abuses and urges tougher laws
text: A U.S. House of Representatives panel looking into abuses of market power by four of the biggest technology companies found they used "killer acquisitions" to smite rivals, charged exorbitant fees, and forced small businesses into "oppressive" contracts in the name of profit.

title: Congress should consider breaking up Big Tech and limiting acquisitions, House report says
text: Big Tech poses a grave threat to markets that might require breaking up the most prominent U.S. tech companies and limiting their acquisitions, concluded a House subcommittee report issued Tuesday.

title: House Democrats say Facebook, Amazon, Alphabet, Apple enjoy 'monopoly power' and recommend big changes
text: Republicans have voiced objections to some of the bolder proposals in the report, like imposing structural separations.

title: Big Tech shares drop amid reports House subcommittee wants to split them up
text: Shares of Amazon.com Inc., Google parent Alphabet Inc. [GOOG], Facebook Inc., and Apple Inc. were down Tuesday amid reports that a House subcommittee that has investigated anticompetitive business practices for more than a year is set to recommend splitting them up and limiting the scope of their future acquisitions.

title: House panel’s probe into Big Tech reportedly draws skepticism from Republicans
text: A key congressional committee is poised to call for a crackdown on Big Tech companies — but some Republicans are already balking at its proposals, according to reports. The House Judiciary Committee’s antitrust panel is expected to release a highly anticipated report this week detailing the findings of its yearlong probe into the market dominance.

title: Gene Munster on why Facebook could be the platform most at risk of regulation
text: Gene Munster, Loup Ventures, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss the tech wreck and why he thinks Facebook is the most at risk of being regulated and why this time is different.

title: House looks to break up big tech: Report
text: A House of Representatives subcommittee on antitrust will publish a report on Big Tech following a year-long investigation, according to Bloomberg. Yahoo Finance's Akiko Fujita discusses.

title: Final Trades: Starbucks, Facebook, Zimmer Holdings & more
text: The "Halftime Report" traders give their top picks to watch for the second half.

title: Facebook revenue chief says ad-supported model is ‘under assault’ amid Apple privacy changes
text: The change to Apple's identifier for advertisers, or IDFA,will give iPhone users the option to block tracking when opening an app. Facebook calls it a threat to the ad-supported business model that's helped the internet grow.

title: Big Tech Stocks Fall On House Report Threatening Antitrust Action
text: Amazon.com, Apple and other Big Tech firms saw their shares fall Tuesday on reports that a House Judiciary panel plans to recommend antitrust action, including possible forced breakups. The post Big Tech Stocks Fall On House Report Threatening Antitrust Action appeared first on Investor's Business Daily.

title: Details of the House's antitrust probe have been leaked—Here's what we know
text: Details of the House antitrust subcommittee's report on Big Tech have been leaked. CNBC's Ylan Mui reports.

title: Political Ad Debate Is a Temporary Distraction for Facebook
text: The vitriolic political race hasn’t done any favors for Facebook stock but don’t forget that this ugly drama will eventually end. The post Political Ad Debate Is a Temporary Distraction for Facebook appeared first on InvestorPlace.

title: If the Democrats win the Senate, Big Tech better be ready for a bigger fight
text: Democratic senators have signaled a willingness to make substantial changes to antitrust law and advocate breakups of the largest American tech companies, including campaigning for president on the issue. If the party can flip four seats, those same senators — such as Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts — could be in position to act against some of their favorite targets, including Facebook Inc. and Google parent Alphabet Inc.

title: Key GOP lawmaker lays out 'non-starters' for Big Tech antitrust reform
text: The divergence leaves an opening for the powerful tech companies to oppose legislation that could install greater regulatory burdens.

title: Facebook Vows to Go Rogue and Not Comply With New Turkish Social Media Law
text: It's the first platform to defy the new law that went into effect on Oct. 1.

title: Mark Hulbert: What Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet have in common with 1970s ‘Nifty-Fifty’ stocks
text: Many stock-market bears are comparing today’s “FAAMG” stocks to the “Nifty Fifty” stocks that dominated the U.S. market in the early 1970s — and which were decimated in the 1973-74 bear market.

title: Hold Your Facebook Shares as the Company Fights for Legitimacy
text: In a contentious election year, Facebook has opportunities to repair its image and that's potentially good news for Facebook stock holders. The post Hold Your Facebook Shares as the Company Fights for Legitimacy appeared first on InvestorPlace.

title: Whistleblower Reveals New Information To House On Facebook-Instagram Deal: CNBC
text: A congressional report looking into the monopolistic practices of big technology companies has been delayed after the House Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust received new information on Facebook Inc (NASDAQ: FB) acquisition of Instagram, CNBC reported Monday.  What Happened: The report has already been delayed twice, once on account of a whistleblower who provided new information on the 2012 Facebook-Instagram deal and the second time on Monday after Republican lawmakers said they wanted to add their input, according to CNBC.
